Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting:
Evolving Environments for Evolving Solutions

(2) Summary

The idea of digital transformation leads many organizations to more decentralized IT architectures: Instead of driving IT top-down in a one-size-fits-all approach, the goal becomes to move away from mandating one single way how to build applications. The focus then is on what needs to be done to create and manage a loosely coupled and evolvable landscape of digital products. These landscapes not just evolve in terms of the products that are developed in them, but they also evolve in terms of what the landscapes support, and possibly what kind of tooling is made available as a service to product teams. Continuous Architecting is a new way of thinking about architecture, where the main goal is to observe how well the capabilities and constraints of an IT landscape work for product architects, and to continuously adjust and improve these capabilities and constraints, so that products can be designed, developed, and deployed more easily.

Why APIs? Why Microservices? Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting:
Evolving Environments for Evolving Solutions

(11) Microservices 101

  • You know what products teams are delivering but not how they are producing them
  • There can be no hidden dependencies between products
  • Delivery velocity increases because teams can pick tools and can move at their own speed
  • Consumers satisfaction increases because products get released and changed more quickly


Why APIs? Why Microservices? Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting:
Evolving Environments for Evolving Solutions

(12) Microservices Corollary

  • Minimizing constraints maximizes team autonomy and thus productivity
  • Coherence across products must be explicitly designed and managed
  • Identifying and supporting cross-product concerns increases landscape productivity
  • Building robustness against change into the landscape is critical


Why APIs? Why Microservices? Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting:
Evolving Environments for Evolving Solutions

(13) API Archaeology

  • Existing organizations face considerable brownfield transformation issues
  • Virtually all organizations have proto-APIs from integration projects
  • Understanding and potentially replacing proto-APIs gets API initiatives underway
  • Enterprise architecture needs to embrace and continuously improve API practices

Enterprise Architecture Trends Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting:
Evolving Environments for Evolving Solutions

(15) Decentralization

  • Increase speed of innovation and time to initial release
  • Decrease dependency on release speed of other products
  • Improve correspondence between business and IT structures


Enterprise Architecture Trends Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting:
Evolving Environments for Evolving Solutions

(16) Heterogeneity

  • Allow teams to use the right tools for their jobs
  • Encourage good practices but never paint yourself into one corner
  • Observe patterns and practices and promote/support the successful ones


Enterprise Architecture Trends Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting:
Evolving Environments for Evolving Solutions

(17) Loosely Coupled

  • Use API First as a way to minimize the coupling surface
  • Cultivate APIs as the way how teams communicate
  • Teach and promote ways to make the language open and extensible

Landscapes and Evolution Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting:
Evolving Environments for Evolving Solutions

(19) APIs, API Landscapes, and Landscape Evolution

  • An API is the actionable representation of a product in your organization
  • The API Landscape is the representation of available capabilities of your organization
  • Landscape Evolution is driven by consumers, producers, and the production environment


Landscapes and Evolution Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting:
Evolving Environments for Evolving Solutions

(20) Chaos Engineering! Chaos Architecting?



Landscapes and Evolution Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting:
Evolving Environments for Evolving Solutions

(21) Continuous Architecting



Landscapes and Evolution Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting:
Evolving Environments for Evolving Solutions

(22) Evolution: Products and Environments

  • Level 1: Products evolve to increase individual fitness
    • Products are evaluated for fitness based on the environment
    • Feedback about products helps to increase their fitness
  • Level 2: Environment changes trigger fitness function changes
    • Changes in the environment are outside the control of products
    • Product fitness changes without products changing
  • Level 3: Environment tweaks are introduced for tweaking fitness
    • Products are given new constraints that impact their fitness
    • Constraints are based on predicted environment conditions/evolution


Architecture Properties

Outline (Architecture Properties)

  1. Introduction [4]
  2. Why APIs? Why Microservices? [5]

Architecture Properties Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting:
Evolving Environments for Evolving Solutions

(24) Observation and Support

  • Observation of explicit (API the APIs) and behavioral aspects
  • The usual suspects are gathering data and knowing what to look for
  • Emerging patterns and trends can indicate investment areas


Architecture Properties Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting:
Evolving Environments for Evolving Solutions

(25) Constraint-Based

  • Create rules what to do and not how to do it
  • When you say what to do also explain why this constraint exists
  • Propose/suggest/support at least one way how to satisfy the constraint
  • Be open to new ways of how constraints can be satisfied
  • Explain how to verify compliance with the constraint


Architecture Properties Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting:
Evolving Environments for Evolving Solutions

(26) Tweaking the Environment

  • Engineering the Engineers
  • Create the environment that helps good products thrive
  • API landscapes need observation and gardening


Architecture Properties Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting:
Evolving Environments for Evolving Solutions

(27) Modular and Evolvable

  • Different constraints may be appropriate for different landscape areas
  • Encourage products to be evolvable to improve their long-term fitness
  • Always strictly separate interface and implementation issues

Conclusions Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting:
Evolving Environments for Evolving Solutions

(29) Continuous Architecting: Research Angles

  1. Observation: Moving from analytical to behavioral
  2. Insights: Creating meaningful insights from behavioral observations
  3. Explicit Support: Identifying trends and finding ways to support them
  4. Engineering the engineers: Tweaking the environment to favor preferred outcomes


Conclusions Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting:
Evolving Environments for Evolving Solutions
